The human body ensures that nutrients and oxygen are evenly distributed to all its cells and tissues through the circulatory system. This system, comprising the heart, blood vessels (arteries, veins, and capillaries), and blood, functions as a network to transport blood throughout the body. The heart acts as a pump, pushing oxygen-rich blood and nutrients into the arterial system. From here, the arteries carry the oxygenated blood away from the heart to various parts of the body.

As blood travels through the arteries, it reaches capillaries, the smallest blood vessels, where the actual exchange of oxygen and nutrients for carbon dioxide and waste products takes place. Through the thin walls of the capillaries, oxygen and nutrients diffuse out of the blood and into the cells, while carbon dioxide and waste products move from the cells into the blood. This process ensures that each cell receives the necessary oxygen and nutrients to perform its functions.

After this exchange, the now oxygen-depleted, carbon dioxide-rich blood is collected into veins, which return it back to the heart. From the heart, it is pumped to the lungs, where it releases carbon dioxide and picks up fresh oxygen during respiration. Then, the oxygen-rich blood returns to the heart, ready to be circulated throughout the body again. This cycle maintains a continuous supply of oxygen and nutrients to all cells and tissues, ensuring their proper function and the overall health of the body.
